Detailed Description

template<typename TqperpGenerate, typename TqperpCalculate, std::size_t numOfRandoms>
class GlvRadiative3< TqperpGenerate, TqperpCalculate, numOfRandoms >

Author:
Simon Wicks <simonw@phys.columbia.edu> Radiative energy loss from Gyulassy-Levai-Vitev, to multiple orders in opacity This object fits into the interface of 'Driver'. It calculates the result for GLV multiple orders in opacity, with the restrictions: 1) fixed temperature medium 2) uncorrelated scattering, with exponential decay distribution between them
In order to allow for testing different various different methods of calculating the necessary q_perp vectors and their necessary dot products, this class is templatized to allow the dropping in at compile time of different classes to do these tasks.

Template parameters: TqperpGenerate: takes uniform random numbers supplied, converts them into numbers distributed from 0 to q_max, with a 'weight' given to correspond to the Gyulassy-Wang collision distribution (or other). The produced randoms can be uniformly distributed from 0 to q_max with Yukawa weights, or Yukawa weighted from 0 to q_max with a weight of 1, or some other choice. This object has the interface: .SetParameters( temperature, jet energy, debye mu ) .GetQsThetas( boost::array<double, numOfRandoms>& randoms, boost::array<double, n>& Qs, boost::array<double, n>& Thetas ) .GetQsEventWeight( long i )

TqperpCalculate: takes the 2D q_perp vectors in polar coords, finds all necessary dot products needed for the GLV calculation. This has the interface: .SetK( double k ) .SetQsThetas( boost::array<double, n>& Qs, boost::array<double, n>& Thetas ) double .GetSumQskk( long k, long zeroes ) double .GetSumQs1k( long k, long zeroes )

numOfRandoms: the number of random numbers needed to produce the result (note that the order in opacity is not numOfRandoms, it's given by n - defined below)

Definition at line 64 of file glvradiative3.h.

Member Function Documentation

template<typename TqperpGenerate, typename TqperpCalculate, std::size_t numOfRandoms>
double GlvRadiative3< TqperpGenerate, TqperpCalculate, numOfRandoms >::GetKmax (  )  const [inline, private]

As the GLV calculation only strictly applies for x<<1 and collinear, eikonal radiation, a rough kinematic cutoff has to be applied to the k integration. The Monte Carlo might not know about this when supplying (x,k) pairs, so we need to simply return 0 for these.

template<typename TqperpGenerate, typename TqperpCalculate, std::size_t numOfRandoms>
double GlvRadiative3< TqperpGenerate, TqperpCalculate, numOfRandoms >::Interference ( long  m,
long  zeroes 
) const [inline, private]

An interference term. In the correlated case, this is a bunch of cosines. But in this special case when the scatters are 'uncorrelated' and distributed exp(-L/lambda), this gives a simpler form.

template<typename TqperpGenerate, typename TqperpCalculate, std::size_t numOfRandoms>
double GlvRadiative3< TqperpGenerate, TqperpCalculate, numOfRandoms >::Summation ( long  mmin,
long  zeroes 
) const [inline, private]

Calls interference*cdotb multiple times, summing over all m values from mmin to n. The choice of mmin depends on whether we want to include the classical diffusion terms (which don't contribute to dN/dx, but do alter the shape of dN/dxdk).

00397   {
00398     result += Interference( m, zeroes ) * CdotB( m, zeroes );
00399   }
00400   return -2.*result;
00401 }

00159   // Check that the opacity order in the input file matches
00160   // that of our compiled executable. The opacity is not a runtime choice,
00161   // it's a compile time choice - this just makes sure that it matches, and that
00162   // the opacity is understood by the user
00163   ReturnedParamsLong = inParams.GetParametersLong( "@opacityOrder" );
00164   long opac = ReturnedParamsLong[0];
00165   if ( opac != n )
00166   {
00167     // The opacity doesn't match!!
00168     // Remember that n is defined as a static long above
00169     std::cerr << "Radcalcer, run time opacity doesn't match that set at compile time.\n";
00170     std::cerr << "For possible optimization purposes, opacity is chosen at compile time";

00174 
00175   // First, we get the parameters of the medium
00176   // This is: 1st = mu, 2nd = temperature, 3rd = gluon mass, 4th = gluon mean free path
00177   // Here, we only need the gluon mass
00178   // the zDist will need the others
00179   ReturnedParamsDouble = inParams.GetParametersDouble( "@mediumParams" );
00180   _mg2 = ReturnedParamsDouble[2]*ReturnedParamsDouble[2];
00181   _temperature = ReturnedParamsDouble[1];
00182   _gluonlambda = ReturnedParamsDouble[3];
00183   _mu = ReturnedParamsDouble[0];
00184

00187   std::string jetFlavour = ReturnedParamsString.front();

00189   {
00190     _cr = 3.; _mass2 = _mg2;
00191   }
00192   else if ( jetFlavour == "Light" )

00194     _cr = 4./3.; _mass2 = _mg2 / 2;

00198     _cr = 4./3.; _mass2 = 1.2*1.2;

00201   {
00202     _cr = 4./3.; _mass2 = 4.75*4.75;
00203   }
00204   else
00205   {

00207     exit(0);
00208   }
00209 
00210   // Now, check whether also specifying a jet mass
00211   ReturnedParamsDouble = inParams.GetParametersDouble( "@jetMassDirect" );
00212   if ( ReturnedParamsDouble.size() > 0 )
00213     _mass2 = ReturnedParamsDouble[0]*ReturnedParamsDouble[0];
00214   
00215   // Now, the momentum, to give the jet energy
00216   ReturnedParamsDouble = inParams.GetParametersDouble( "@jetMomentum" );
00217   double jetMomentum = ReturnedParamsDouble[0];
00218   // Now calculate and set energy, and mass
00219   _en = sqrt( _mass2 + jetMomentum*jetMomentum );
00220   _overEn = 1. / _en;
00221 
00222   // The jet path length in the medium
00223   ReturnedParamsDouble = inParams.GetParametersDouble( "@pathLength" );
00224   _length = ReturnedParamsDouble[0];
00225 
00226   // The setting on the k max
00227   ReturnedParamsLong = inParams.GetParametersLong( "@limitSet" );
00228   _switchkmax = ReturnedParamsLong[0];
00229 
00230   // The strong coupling, alpha_s
00231   ReturnedParamsString = inParams.GetParametersString( "@alpha" );
00232   it = ReturnedParamsString.begin();
00233   if ( *it == "fixed" )
00234   {
00235     ++it;
00236     _alphas = boost::lexical_cast<double>( *it );
00237   }
00238   else
00239   {
00240     std::cerr << "Radcalcer, @alpha not understood";
00241     std::cerr << std::endl;
00242     exit(0);

template<typename TqperpGenerate, typename TqperpCalculate, std::size_t numOfRandoms>
void GlvRadiative3< TqperpGenerate, TqperpCalculate, numOfRandoms >::SetCoord ( long  dimension,
double  value 
) [inline]

Setting x and k Note that setting x requires no recalculation of the q-vectors; setting k does need a little recalculation. Hence, iterating over x for fixed k will be more efficient than iterating over k for fixed x.

template<typename TqperpGenerate, typename TqperpCalculate, std::size_t numOfRandoms>
void GlvRadiative3< TqperpGenerate, TqperpCalculate, numOfRandoms >::SetRandoms ( boost::array< double, numOfRandoms > &  randomNumbers  )  [inline]

Pass in random number distributed from [0,1), use them to set Q and Theta as necessary. This uses the TqperpGenerator object to convert into [0,qmax), then uses TqperpCalculator to do all necessary calculation for this set of Qs and Thetas
